Award.AwardTitle: Universal Versus Culturally Constructed Aspects of Consumption

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Jon Holtzman of Western Michigan University will explore the biological and cultural processes that inform preferences for particular kinds of foods. The project will engage approaches varyingly emphasizing universal dimensions of the human experience of eating versus those placing a greater emphasis on cultural specificity. As such, the project aims to contribute to multi-disciplinary approaches to the study of taste as well as engage with debates in nutrition and public health. The project will use a combination qualitative and quantitative methods to examine attitudes, experiences, and patterns of use concerning food consumption.

This question is best pursued by examining sweetness, a taste for which a broad range of scientific fields attribute a unique and largely deterministic power over humans. That scientific literature has thus far emphasized either the parallels between neurological responses to sugar and psychoactive drugs, suggesting an evolutionarily hardwired attraction to sweetness, or it has been influenced by research on the global "nutrition transition" that suggests increased access to sugar concomitant with rising incomes almost inevitably contributes to epidemic obesity. Anthropologists have tended towards a more circumspect approach to sweetness and other basic tastes, usually acknowledging universal aspects to the human sensory experiences of taste but emphasizing the need to understand how these are shaped and given meaning in particular cultural and historical contexts. Japan has been chosen as the principal site for assessing universal versus culturally constructed approaches to sugar because it is a notable outlier to global obesity trends despite high levels of wealth and sugar access. One possible explanation for this Japan's outlier status is the influence of intricate Japanese food systems that tie eating to social, aesthetic, and moral values, which the project aims to examine.

By understanding what factors limit sweet consumption and the concomitant health issues associated with excessive sweet use the project aims to assess the relative important of cultural constructions of taste versus more deterministic conceptions, while also offering insights into issues regarding food consumption that will have a direct impact on public health debates in the U.S. and globally.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project examined cultural factors underlying the use and impact of sugar in Japan. Using a combination of qualitative and quantitative ethnographic methods the project critically examined assumptions from a variety of fields that maintain that sugar has an unstoppable, largely pre-cultural and negative impact particularly in respect to obesity and related health issues. Examples of such assumptions may be found in the field of public health, where it is frequently maintained that when societies get ready access to affordable sugar they will inevitably experience high rates of obesity, and in fields such as psychology and neuroscience that assert similarities in human responses to sugar and highly addictive drugs, such as opioids, thus implying that sugar consumption is near impossible to control. This project built on the observation that despite being a wealthy nation with ready access to sugar, having a high liking for sweets, as well as highly elaborated cultural practices involving sweet foods, Japan has the lowest obesity rate among developed nations. Thus, the project aimed to understand the cultural practices and attitudes—regarding sweet foods and eating in general—that have led to Japanese controlling both obesity and the allegedly inevitable impact of sugar.

            The project involved a variety of methods, undertaken mainly in Kyoto, Japan, with short terms visits to other sites in order to check on the representativeness of the main site. Quantitative data mainly involved a survey on food preferences and cravings undertaken with an age-balanced sample of Japanese subjects. Qualitative methods included a series of approximately 80 interviews focusing on attitudes and practices concerning eating, various foods, and weight control. The data and analysis undertaken to date suggest a number of findings of importance both to scholarly understandings of food, eating and health that also have implications for the societal control of obesity. In respect to sugar specifically, the explicit focus of the study, there was little evidence that sugar, or a particular Japanese cultural relationship to sugar, had a major impact on the notable differences between obesity rates in Japan and elsewhere. There was ample evidence that sugar was highly liked, widely eaten and ubiquitously available—seen in individual reports on preferences and behavior, direct observation of behavior and documentation of cultural institutions—but there was no evidence that individuals took marked measures to control intake of sugar specifically. Nor did respondents highlight sugar as a particular item that adversely affected health or led to obesity, tending to emphasize instead total caloric intake and to some extent fried/high fat foods. While specific, conscious individual control of sugar intake was rare (except among individuals who reported being pre-diabetic, and who also tended to aim to limit carbohydrates in general) sugar/sweet items also were less craved than is typically reported in American/European settings (based on an interview instrument specifically focusing on craving) and what would be expected given the extent that the consumption of sugar is frequently regarded as uncontrollable, even addictive. While chocolate specifically was highly liked and among the more commonly craved foods, rates of chocolate craving were far below those found in studies of American/European subjects, and within the sample on par with such items as salad, miso soup and ramen (and well below reported levels for rice).

            Consequently, the study suggests that focus on sugar specifically, or particular foods in general, is likely misplaced in respect to overeating. In Japan, a number of social and behavioral factors relating to eating, health and body image appeared to be far more important in limiting obesity. For instance, alongside a strong individual and social emphasis on maintaining thinness—both in respect to body image and a concern for health even among individuals who would be considered thin by international standards--it is found to be commonplace and socially acceptable for friends, family members and acquaintances to comment on even modest weight gain; Eating frequently occurs within such groups and food is typically shared, such that there is often social pressure to limit what one eats; Impulse eating is controlled by a near taboo on eating in public places (excepting dining establishments). In many professions individuals undergo a health check through one’s employer on at least an annual basis, and those who exceed stringent guidelines are pushed towards health counseling or other interventions; Portion sizes are typically small, in part because they are considered healthier, in part because food wastage by failing to finish a larger portion is considered problematic, and because some express anxiety about the discomfort of eating too much. Thus, while recognizing that some foods/dietary patterns—including the typical Japanese one--are less prone to cause obesity, societal factor that promote or enforce calorie restriction are likely a much more important factor in observed differences in Japanese rates of obesity.
